intro: Loranthus krausei, commonly known as the Krause’s mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant that attaches to the branches of its host trees, primarily in the genus *Eucalyptus*. It lacks chlorophyll and relies on its host for water and nutrients, while producing its own sugars through photosynthesis using light reflected from the host. The plant has small, oval-shaped leaves and produces white or pale green berries that contain sticky seeds. It is native to Australia and is often found in coastal regions. Its presence can have both positive and negative effects on the health of its host tree.
